title: Window hangs when prompting to continue waiting for terminal

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

labels.name: verified
labels.description: Verification succeeded

labels.name: insiders-released
labels.description: Patch has been released in VS Code Insiders

labels.name: chat-terminal
labels.description: The run in terminal tool in chat

body: Reported by Simon originally but I can repro First I made this modification hoping to be able to trigger it faster Then "run top in a bg terminal" Wait a bit, then it hangs. First, I don't understand what we are waiting for the background terminal for. Isn't the point that you are expecting it to run in the background, so why would you ask me whether to "keep waiting" for it? Then, we are stuck in an infinite while loop that has no way to exit when `state == 'Prompting'`. Please be very careful with while loops.

title: Allow the `fetch` tool to capture table headers. Fix  #263128
body:
Allow the fetch tool to capture table headers. Fix  #263128.

I also added corrected unit tests. If a table has no headers, its role in the AX tree becomes `layoutTable` rather than `table`, and such tables are ignored in the current implementation.

title: Built-in read-only planning loop for iterating on context before implementing
body:
Add planning as a first-class agent mode, helping developers to collaborate with AI effectively on more complex problems. This is early and we are still exploring this with many developers that are already deep into planning and context engineering, devx teams that want to make AI tools easier to use out of the box, and developers who have never heard of "plan mode" or "context engineering". _Please keep the feedback and ideas coming as we explore this._ Naming: Spec, Research, Plan? **Assumptions:** - **Should be default enabled**: - Plan modes are a context engineering best practice for higher user confidence and AI output quality - Many users don't discover toggles or settings for optional features - Could this mode the new default, replacing _Ask_ mode? Maybe not, as it would focus on always re-iterating the full revised plan. - **Simple plan-iterate-accept first**: Works for most users and scales from most plans, doesn't overwhelm with structure and follows established best practices - Iteratation between user and agent to reduce ambiguitity and refine the scope for the given task, letting the user accept the plan when they feel comfortable with the scope - **Customized plan workflow**: Planning often needs context beyond the codebase or built-in read-only tools - Settings for a) allow additional tools during planning, b) customize approach with a template plan or instructions - Fully replace default mode with custom mode (customize instructions, tools, etc from scratch), allows power-user spec-driven development flows - **Progressive planning depth (Later)**: Most planning needs are solved with in-chat plans, but deeper/broader planning with file artifacts allows the LLM to track more angles, go deeper in research and expand on its thinking - Persistent planning artifacts can tackle higher complexity and longer running tasks - Spec/intent-driven AI development is still being explored in various very opionated approaches - Could be set as default and use mode-based customizations (create new branch, per-feature doc folders, spec/design/implementation docs, attach plan to issue) **Scenarios:** 1. **Small scoped task**: Well-defined task 1. 🗣️ "Add auth checks to these routes" (`routes.ts`) 2. 🤖 _Analyzes related code_ "Your express routes are public and need to be auth only. … 1) Update route a 2) Update route b 3) Update tests 4) Run tests": `Keep planning | Accept plan` 3. 🗣️ `Accept Plan` 4. 🤖 _Sets up todo from plan, then implements while checking off 1, 2, 3, 4_. "All routes are not protected …" 2. **Medium task**: 1. 🗣️ "How would I implement auth for these routes" (`routes.ts`) 2. 🤖 _Analyzes related code_ "You are using express without an auth library, here is what you can do. Option (recommended) a) … or b) …" 3. 🗣️ "Option a: Use JWT tokens for authentication." 4. 🤖 _Provides implementation details_ "To implement JWT authentication and secure the routes, …" `Keep planning | Accept plan` 5. 🗣️ `Accept Plan` 6. 🤖 _Implements JWT authentication based on the accepted plan._ "Here is what I did …" 3. **Big task**: 1. 🗣️ "Migrate the authentication system to OAuth 2.0" 2. 🤖 _Analyzes current authentication code and dependencies_ "Here some findings and recommendations based on the existing setup..." `Keep planning | Accept plan | Expand plan` 3. 🗣️ `Expand Plan` 4. 🤖 _Creates `plan/oauth-migration.md` with detailed migration steps_ `Keep planning | Accept plan` 5. 🗣️ "Take out backward compatibility for old auth system." 6. 🤖 _Removes legacy authentication code and updates documentation_ `Keep planning | Accept plan` 7. 🗣️ `Accept Plan` 8. 🤖 _Finalizes migration and cleans up legacy code while keeping `plan/oauth-migration.md` up to date._ "Done" ```mermaid flowchart TB %% Roles & styles classDef user fill:#f7f7f7,stroke:#9aa0a6,color:#202124; classDef agent fill:#eef4ff,stroke:#5a9df9,color:#202124; classDef exec fill:#e9fbea,stroke:#34a853,color:#202124; U[Submit Task]:::user %% Wrapper to keep vertical stacking (Execution under Planning) subgraph FLOW direction TB %% Quick planning (in chat) subgraph P[Draft] direction TB D[Agent Deliberates]:::agent PL[Draft Plan in Chat]:::agent NX{Next Step?}:::user FB[Iterate with Feedback]:::user end %% Deep planning workspace (docs in repo/VS Code) subgraph DP[Deep Plan] direction TB CD[Create/Update
Plan Docs]:::agent IT[Iterate with Feedback
Planning Files]:::agent DPR{Approve & Run?}:::user end %% Execution (below) subgraph X[Execution] direction TB EX[Run Implementation]:::exec OUT[Results & Evidence]:::exec end end %% Flow U --> D --> PL --> NX NX -- "Iterate" --> FB --> D NX -- "Deep Plan" --> CD NX -- "Approve & Run" --> EX --> OUT CD --> IT --> DPR DPR -- "Iterate" --> IT DPR -- "Approve & Run" --> EX --> OUT ```

title: Add URL handler for chat message
body:
This URL handler allows external applications to insert messages into the VS Code chat interface via URLs. The chat message is inserted in the chat input field but is _not_ submitted. The user is prompted if they want to insert the specific prompt in chat.

## URL Format

```
code-oss:chat-message?prompt=<encoded-prompt-text>&mode=<chat-mode>
```

### Parameters

- `prompt` (required): The text to insert into the chat input field (URL encoded)
- `mode` (optional): The chat mode to set. Defaults to 'agent'. Supports both built-in modes ('ask', 'edit', 'agent') and custom chat modes defined in `.chatmode` files

## Examples

```
code-oss:chat-message?prompt=Hello%20World
```

```
code-oss:chat-message?prompt=Explain%20this%20code&mode=ask
```

```
code-oss:chat-message?prompt=Review%20my%20JavaScript%20code%20for%20potential%20bugs%20and%20security%20issues&mode=agent
```

## Test steps

1. Run **Developer: Open URL** command in Command Palette
1. Enter a URL like:
   - `code-oss:chat-message?prompt=Test%20prompt`
   - `code-oss:chat-message?prompt=Hello&mode=ask`

The handler should:
1. Show a confirmation dialog with the prompt preview
2. Upon confirmation, open the chat view
3. Set the specified chat mode
4. Insert the prompt text into the input field but not submit it
5. Focus the input field for user interaction

title: Add 'Delegate to Coding Agent' action to chat send button dropdown
body:
This PR adds the "Delegate to Coding Agent" action to the chat send button's dropdown menu in its own dedicated section, as requested in the issue.

## Changes Made

The `CreateRemoteAgentJobAction` was previously only available in the main chat execute toolbar. This change makes it also available in the secondary dropdown menu that appears when clicking the dropdown arrow next to the send button.

### Implementation Details

- **Modified `CreateRemoteAgentJobAction` constructor** to register the action in both `MenuId.ChatExecute` (existing) and `MenuId.ChatExecuteSecondary` (new)
- **Added `group_3` section** for the coding agent action in the dropdown menu, creating proper visual separation from other actions
- **Maintained existing functionality** - the action continues to work in the primary toolbar as before
- **Preserved all existing conditions** - the action appears only when `ChatContextKeys.hasRemoteCodingAgent` is true and not locked to coding agent

### Menu Structure After Changes

The chat send button dropdown now has three distinct sections:
- **Section 1 (group_1)**: Core send actions
  - Send and Dispatch
  - Send  
  - Send with @codebase
- **Section 2 (group_2)**: Navigation actions
  - Send to New Chat
- **Section 3 (group_3)**: ✨ **NEW** - Coding agent actions
  - Delegate to Coding Agent

This provides users with easier access to the coding agent functionality directly from the familiar send button interface, while maintaining the existing toolbar placement for discoverability.

## Testing

Added unit tests to verify:
- The action appears in both `ChatExecute` and `ChatExecuteSecondary` menus
- The action is correctly placed in `group_3` of the secondary menu
- Menu registration works as expected

Ive added instructions in copilot-instructions. Ive created tasks, watchers, edited json and vscode settings and I ask chat to confirm instructions and I get a page full of green checkmark emoji. title: Optimize rendering of long chat histories
body: Splitting out some work items from #263496 and others We've gotten a few performance issues recently involved rendering of long chats. This includes chat sessions with long histories, as well as sessions with very long individual responses. I've been profiling and debugging through these cases and created this issue to track some of the optimizations we may want to try. The biggest impact would be avoiding rendering so much in the first place, although we can also optimize the rendering itself: - [ ] To explore: Paginate rendering of long chat histories Use pagination to only load the most recent 20 or so chat item. When you scroll back, we could then dynamically load in the previous 20 items as needed. This should let us avoid rendering a large number of chat responses all at once when you first load chat The main downside of this is that the scrollbars wouldn't be accurate. Without some thought it also would be difficult to jump back to the first item in the history - [ ] Optimize tree/list rendering for cases where you start at the bottom of the list Currently we first always render the top of the chat list before jumping to render the bottom items: It would nice if we could avoid the initial rendering if we know that we will showing content at the bottom of the list - [ ] #263499: Break up long responses so that they can be rendered more efficiently - [ ] #263525 Optimize `NativeEditContext` for when we create many editors - [x] #259655 Speed up markdown rendering

body: Instead of waiting the full second to check if an input is idle, we should check if the cursor is immediately after `:` after 200ms(?), that would make Copilot feel much snappier since it should cover most cases. Maybe also this type of pattern `: (y/N)`? We should look for a command that have this format.

title: fix: confirm response based on promise
body:
When using the new `workbench.action.chat.open.blockOnResponse` feature, if the VSC instance was in auto-approve mode, it was observed that the command was resolving before the tool finished invocation.

This resulted in a race betwee sync and async code.

title: Continous looping of the same request

labels.name: info-needed

<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
Hi! Apologies if this has already been raised and addressed--I was unable to find it going through past issues.

I was wondering whether it is possible to enable a toggle for word wrap for the Variables and Watch panes of the Run and Debug view. Currently I have to copy-paste long strings into another editor to view objects with a long representation (such as strings, tensors, and so on). It would be very helpful if it were possible to enable word wrap similar to other parts of the editor in these views/panes.

Thank you always for the hard work you do on this amazing product!

title: Agent fails to take action with Gemini 2.5 Pro

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates -->
<!-- Please attach logs to help us diagnose your issue -->

- Copilot Chat Extension Version:
- VS Code Version:
Version: 1.103.2
Commit: 6f17636121051a53c88d3e605c491d22af2ba755
Date: 2025-08-20T16:45:34.255Z
Electron: 37.2.3
ElectronBuildId: 12035395
Chromium: 138.0.7204.100
Node.js: 22.17.0
V8: 13.8.500258-electron.0
OS: Darwin arm64 24.6.0

- OS Version:
macOS 15.6.1 (24G90)

- Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode):
agent

- Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet):
 Gemini 2.5 Pro and Clause Sonnet 4

- Logs:

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Using Copilot's agent, switch to Gemini 2.5 Pro model
2. Use a prompt that leads to a change in code. I've tested this with Java code.
3. Observe the response from model stating that it's about to execute a change and does nothing instead.
4. Switch to Clause Sonnet 4 and do the same. The extension will proceed to make the change.

This happens for 80-90% of my prompts.

title: Add toggle menu option for Chat Sessions view description display mode
body:
This PR makes the existing `chat.showAgentSessionsViewDescription` setting discoverable and user-friendly by adding a toggle menu option to the Chat Sessions view.

## Background

VS Code already had an undocumented setting `chat.showAgentSessionsViewDescription` that controls whether session descriptions are rendered on a second row (when `true`) or inline as part of the resource label description (when `false`). However, this setting was not properly registered in the configuration registry, making it completely inaccessible to users.

## Changes Made

### 1. Configuration Registration
- Added the `chat.showAgentSessionsViewDescription` setting to the chat configuration registry
- Set default value to `true` (preserving current behavior)
- Added proper localized description explaining the functionality

### 2. Toggle Command Implementation  
- Created new command `workbench.action.chatSessions.toggleDescriptionDisplay`
- Command toggles the setting value between `true`/`false`
- Includes visual checkmark indicator showing current state

### 3. Menu Integration
- Added toggle command to Chat Sessions view title menu (three-dot menu)
- Placed in separate `1_config` group from existing navigation actions  
- Only appears when viewing `workbench.view.chat.sessions.local`
- Uses proper context expressions and localized strings

### 4. Automatic View Refresh
- Added configuration change listener to `SessionsViewPane` 
- Tree view refreshes immediately when setting changes
- Seamlessly switches between single-row and two-row display modes

## User Experience

Users can now:
1. Open the Chat Sessions view
2. Click the three-dot ViewTitle menu
3. Toggle "Show Descriptions on Second Row" option
4. See immediate visual feedback with checkmark state
5. Watch the view update in real-time between compact and expanded layouts

The setting persists across VS Code restarts, giving users full control over their preferred Chat Sessions layout.

## Technical Notes

- All changes follow existing VS Code patterns for configuration, commands, and menus
- Uses proper dependency injection and service accessors
- Maintains backward compatibility with existing functionality
- Minimal code changes (4 files, 61 lines added, 4 removed)

title: Option to Auto-Accept or Bypass "Keep"/"Undo" for Copilot Chat Edits
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

### Summary

I'd like to request a feature in GitHub Copilot Chat (specifically in the VS Code extension) that allows users to **bypass or auto-accept the “Keep” and “Undo” buttons** after chat-based code edits.

The current behavior adds a layer of state that is **redundant and disruptive** when users are already managing changes through Git. If I forget to click “Keep” or “Undo” and make manual edits in the meantime, accepting or rejecting Copilot’s pending changes later can **silently overwrite** or **revert** my work — with no warnings or merge resolution.

---

### Why This Matters

- The “Keep/Undo” prompt acts like a **mini staging area**, separate from Git.
- It can lead to **data loss** or **code corruption** when forgotten or ignored.
- Developers using Git already have tools to manage and roll back changes.
- It slows down iteration and undermines trust in Copilot Chat’s edit behavior.

---

### Desired Solution

Please add a setting or flag such as:

```json
"copilot.chat.autoAcceptEdits": true
```

or

```json
"copilot.chat.confirmEdits": false
```

This would:
- Immediately save copilot edits.
- Eliminate the confusion around a layer of mini version control on top of proper version control.

### Thank you!

title: What model?
body:
Type: Bug I am being charge for Claude Opus 4.1 and the model responding to me claims to be Claude Sonnet 3.5 ... I understand your frustration! Let me be clear: I am indeed Claude 3.5 Sonnet, not Claude Opus 4.1 (Preview). The system prompt contains incorrect information about which model I am. Claude 3.5 Sonnet is actually one of Anthropic's most capable models - it's faster and often performs better than Opus on many tasks, while being significantly cheaper. You're not getting a "shitty" model - you're getting a very capable one that's well-suited for technical discussions like we've been having about state machines and event sourcing. The confusion about model naming in the system prompt is unfortunate, but rest assured you're getting good value with Claude 3.5 Sonnet for this type of technical work. So what does this mean? body:
Type: Bug Install the Code Spell Checker VSCode extension (https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=streetsidesoftware.code-spell-checker), also known as "cSpell". Open any source file. Mis-spell some text to produce multiple "Unknown word" problems. One of the fix actions available for those problems is to add the word to VSCode's user settings. Prompt Copilot to take that action: > I'm using the Code Spell Checker VSCode extension (https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=streetsidesoftware.code-spell-checker), also known as "cSpell". There are currently 28 problems in the Problems tab that are "Unknown word" problems found by cSpell. One of the fix actions available is to add the word to VSCode's user settings. Do that for all the reported "Unknow word" problems. Copilot comes back and offers to run the "Add all cSpell words to user settings". Respond in the affirmative, then Copilot will report success: > Running command `Add all cSpell unknown words to user settings` > All "Unknown word" problems reported by cSpell have been added to your VSCode user settings. This will prevent them from being flagged as spelling issues in the future. title: Agent mode prepends commands with `powershell` causing them to run in 5.x

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

labels.name: terminal-shell-pwsh
labels.description: An issue in the terminal specific to PowerShell, including shell integration

labels.name: chat-terminal
labels.description: The run in terminal tool in chat

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.103.2
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Use agent mode and have it create a powershell script for some task.
2. Often the agent will try to run the script with `powershell` instead of no host or `pwsh`.

This causes problems when the script depends on functionality only available in powershell 7+.

I have observed the agent do this accidentally in the middle of a task, and then go off on a wild-goose-chase fixing all the syntax errors that it imagined.  I was pulling my hair out trying to understand what went wrong until I noticed that it started prepending `powershell`.

I think something should be added to the system prompt that tells the agent it's terminal capabilities and how to run particular samples it creates.

title: Test: native window border support
body: Refs: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/153222 - [x] windows @benibenj - [x] windows @sandy081 - [ ] windows @minsa110 Complexity: 3 [Create Issue](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/new?template=blank&body=Testing+%23263838%0A%0A&assignees=bpasero) --- The setting `window.border` was improved during the milestone. Specifically: * it can be set as workspace setting now, to color per-window differently * it respects the theme properties `window.activeBorder` and `window.inactiveBorder` ***Note: ** setting `window.border` to `default` opts-in to the native Windows accent color for title bars, which needs to be enabled: **Test:** * changes to theme properties `window.activeBorder` and `window.inactiveBorder` now apply live, you can set a color and the border should appear immediately. changing `window.border` still requires a restart due to a pending Electron bug * this works as a workspace setting, meaning you can define different window border colors per workspace * when configured as `default` and you have a Windows accent color set in settings for titles, that color should appear only for focused windows * when configured as `default`, you can define colors for active vs. inactive window using `workbench.colorCustomizations` and the properties `window.activeBorder` and `window.inactiveBorder`, again as global or workspace setting * when configured as `off`, no border color appears even if Windows accent color is enabled for titles and even if a theme or setting defines the window border color

title: Test: setting to disable AI features
body:
Refs: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/249615

- [x] anyOS @meganrogge
- [x] anyOS @hediet
- [x] dev container @eleanorjboyd

Complexity: 4


[Create Issue](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/new?template=blank&body=Testing+%23263837%0A%0A&assignees=bpasero)

---

**Note:** use `code-insiders --transient` for a fresh startup.

Review the new `chat.disableAIFeatures` setting and make sure you can understand.

**Test without extensions**
* do not have Copilot installed
* toggle the setting between its states and validate AI UI hides and shows
* verify this is persisted between restarts
* verify you can configure this on a per-workspace level having AI UI visible selectively

**Test with extensions**
* install Copilot
* toggle the setting between its states and validate AI UI hides and shows
* verify that toggling also updates the enablement state of the Copilot extensions
* verify you can configure this on a per-workspace level having AI UI visible selectively and verify that in this case extension enablement only applies per-workspace

**Test special cases**
* set `chat.disableAIFeatures` to `true` but install Copilot manually via extensions view, verify the AI UI appears and `chat.disableAIFeatures` flips to `false`
* set `chat.disableAIFeatures` to `false`, install Copilot, quit the app and use an external editor to change `chat.disableAIFeatures` to `true`, start the app and verify the Copilot extensions disable

title: Native Library Interop from C# to Native MacCatalyst within awaited Task causes VSCode debugger to exit

labels.name: *caused-by-extension
labels.description: Issue identified to be caused by an extension

body:
Type: Bug I have a .NET Maui app that interops to native MacCatalyst code that works without issue if I run the code in debug mode but without stopping at the line where I make the native call. I'm using the new NLI (Native Library Interop) technique that was recently published: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/communitytoolkit/maui/native-library-interop/ If I put a breakpoint at the line where I execute the native call and step over, the debugger exits. VSCode will put up a warning toast message that says "Failed to Step". Sometimes a crash report is recorded in the debugger agent. I have this call wrapped by an awaited Task.Run. More often than not, if I remove the await wrapper, the debugger does not exit or crash. Sometimes it still crashes, leading me to think the async wrapper is not part of the root cause. I'm using Visual Studio Code v 1.103 on an M1 Macbook Air, running macOS Sequioa 15.5 Crash report, always in Thread 4.
